'''10''' (''[[2008â2009 figure skating season|2008â2009]]'') |combined total= 172.47 |combined date= [[2010 World Figure Skating Championships|2010 World Championships]] |SP score= 60.52 |SP date= [[2010 World Figure Skating Championships|2010 World Championships]] |FS score= 111.95 |FS date= [[2010 World Figure Skating Championships|2010 World Championships]] }} '''Jeremy Barrett''' (born April 10, 1984 in [[Sarasota, Florida]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[pair skater]]. He won the 2010 [[2010 United States Figure Skating Championships|2010 U.S. Championships]] with [[Caydee Denney]], and competed at the 2010 Winter Olympics. == Career == Jeremy Barrett began skating at the age of eight. He competed as a single skater on the novice level at the regional level. His first pairs partner was his sister Shawn-Marie and they competed at the U.S. Junior Championships.[http://www.goldenskate.com/articles/2004/081704.shtml Shantel Jordan and Jeremy Barrett: Top U.S. Junior Pair Team Can Never Make Junior Worlds] In 2001, he teamed up with Shantel Jordan. Because of the age difference between them, they were unable to compete internationally on the junior level. They were the 2004 [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. junior national champions]]. They competed at the 2005 [[French Figure Skating Championships]] as guests and placed 1st on the senior level. Their partnership ended in 2006. Jeremy Barrett is also a national-level figure skating coach. Among his most famous pupils, was Alisha Erozer. He began skating with [[Caydee Denney]] in 2006, but the partnership did not last. They teamed up again in 2008 and began competing in the 2008-2009 season.{{cite news | url = http://web.icenetwork.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081122&content_id=56368&vkey=ice_news | title = Denney and Barrett give it another try | first = Lynn | last = Rutherford |date = November 22, 2008 | work = IceNetwork.com | accessdate = February 25, 2011}} They placed 4th at the [[2008 Nebelhorn Trophy]]. They won the silver medal at the [[2009 United States Figure Skating Championships|2009 U.S. Nationals]]. They placed sixth at the [[2009 Four Continents Championships]]. The following season they won the [[2010 United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. national title]] and the right to compete at the Olympics where they finished 13th. They placed 7th at the World Championships. At the [[2011 United States Figure Skating Championships|2011 U.S. Nationals]], they won the bronze medal and were assigned to compete at Four Continents, however they were forced to withdraw. Denney accidentally sliced Barrett's calf on his right leg while practicing side-by-side jumps. He explained that "It cut all the way to the muscle, so I had to get 12 stitches on the muscles, 14 to close that up and 16 on the outside."{{cite news | url = http://web.icenetwork.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20110212&content_id=16625346&vkey=ice_news | title = Denney, Barrett out of Four Continents | first = Sarah S. | last = Brannen |date = February 12, 2011 | work = IceNetwork.com | accessdate = February 13, 2011}} Denney and Barrett ended their partnership in February 2011. Barrett intends to focus on coaching and performing in shows.{{cite news | url = http://web.icenetwork.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20110224&content_id=16724722&vkey=ice_pressrelease | title = Denney, Barrett announce end of partnership | author = U.S. Figure Skating |date = February 24, 2011 | work = IceNetwork.com | accessdate = February 25, 2011}} == Personal life == Barrett is engaged to pair skater [[Amanda Evora]].http://www.herald-review.com/news/local/article_a6589efa-1a3a-11df-bebe-001cc4c002e0.html ==Programs== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !
